official-title.#text:
To establish the Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children, and for
			 other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committee on

, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such
			 provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds that—

text.#text:
the United States has a distinct legal, treaty, and trust obligation to provide for the education,
			 health care, safety, social welfare, and other needs of Native children;

suicide is the second leading cause of death in Native children aged 15 through 24, a rate that is
			 2.5 times the national average, and violence, including intentional
			 injuries, homicide, and suicide, account for 75 percent of the deaths of
			 Native children aged 12 through 20;

Native children disproportionately enter foster care at a rate more than 2.1 times the general
			 population and have the third highest rate of victimization; and

there is no resource that is more vital to the continued existence and integrity of Native
			 communities than Native children, and the United States has a direct
			 interest, as trustee, in protecting Native children.
In this Act:

quote.#tail: means the Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children established by

text.#text: The

header.#text: Comprehensive study of Native children issues

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall conduct a comprehensive study of Federal, State, local, and tribal programs
			 that serve Native children, including an evaluation of—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children

text.#text: The
the impact of concurrent jurisdiction on child welfare systems;

the obstacles to nongovernmental financial support, such as from private foundations and corporate
			 charities, for programs benefitting Native children;

the barriers to the development of sustainable, multidisciplinary programs designed to assist
			 high-risk Native children and families of those high-risk Native children,
			 as well as any examples of successful program models and use of best
			 practices; and
the barriers to interagency coordination on programs benefitting Native children.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , to avoid duplication of efforts, the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children Act/s:4/ss:d/p:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall,
			 to the maximum extent practicable, collaborate with other workgroups
			 focused on similar issues, such as the Task Force on American
			 Indian/Alaska Native Children Exposed to Violence of the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children

text.#text: In conducting the study under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and the analysis of any
			 existing data relating to Native children received from Federal agencies,
			 the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children Act/s:4/ss:d/p:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children

text.#text: Taking into consideration the results of the study under

make recommendations on necessary modifications and improvements to programs that serve Native
			 children at the Federal, State, and tribal level that integrate the
			 cultural strengths of the communities of the Native children and will
			 result in—
improvements to the child welfare system that—

reduce the disproportionate rate at which Native children enter child protective services and the
			 period of time spent in the foster system;
encourage the hiring and retention of licensed social workers in Native communities;
address the lack of available foster homes in Native communities; and
improve the academic proficiency and graduation rates of Native children in the foster system;

improvements to the mental and physical health of Native children, taking into consideration the
			 rates of suicide, substance abuse, and access to nutrition and health
			 care, including—
an analysis of the increased access of Native children to Medicaid under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and the effect of that increase
			 on the ability of Indian tribes and Native Hawaiians to develop
			 sustainable health programs; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Patient Protection and
			 Affordable Care Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
public-law/111/148

text.#text:
an evaluation of the effects of a lack of public sanitation infrastructure, including in-home sewer
			 and water, on the health status of Native children;
improvements to educational and vocational opportunities for Native children that will lead to—

scholarship opportunities at a Tribal College or University and other public and private
			 postsecondary institutions;
increased participation of the immediate families of Native children;

coordination among schools and Indian tribes that serve Native children, including in the areas of
			 data sharing and student tracking;
accurate identification of students as Native children; and

increased school counseling services, improved access to quality nutrition at school, and safe
			 student transportation;

improved policies and practices by local school districts that would result in improved academic
			 proficiency for Native children;
improvements to Federal, State, and tribal juvenile detention programs—

to provide greater access to educational opportunities and social services for incarcerated Native
			 children;
to promote prevention and reduce incarceration and recidivism rates among Native children;

to incorporate families and the traditional cultures of Indians and Native Hawaiians in the
			 process, including through the development of a family court for juvenile
			 offenses; and
to prevent unnecessary detentions and identify successful reentry programs;

expanded access to a continuum of early development and learning services for Native children from
			 prenatal to age 5 that are culturally competent, support Native language
			 preservation, and comprehensively promote the health, well-being,
			 learning, and development of Native children, such as—

high quality early care and learning programs for children starting from birth, including Early
			 Head Start, Head Start, child care, and preschool programs;

programs, including home visiting and family resource and support programs, that increase the
			 capacity of parents to support the learning and development of the
			 children of the parents, beginning prenatally, and connect the parents
			 with necessary resources;

early intervention and preschool services for infants, toddlers, and preschool-aged children with
			 developmental delays or disabilities; and

professional development opportunities for Native providers of early development and learning
			 services;

the development of a system that delivers wrap-around services to Native children in a way that is
			 comprehensive and sustainable, including through increased coordination
			 among Indian tribes, schools, law enforcement, health care providers,
			 social workers, and families;
more flexible use of existing Federal programs, such as by—

providing Indians and Native Hawaiians with more flexibility to carry out programs, while
			 minimizing administrative time, cost, and expense and reducing the burden
			 of Federal paperwork requirements; and

allowing unexpended Federal funds to be used flexibly across Federal agencies to support programs
			 benefitting Native children, while taking into account—
the 477 Demonstration Initiative of the
the Coordinated Tribal Assistance Solicitation program of the
the Federal policy of self-determination; and
any consolidated grant programs; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, would improve the health, safety,
			 and well-being of Native children;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Alyce Spotted Bear and Walter Soboleff Commission on Native Children

the inclusion of Native children in longitudinal studies; and
tribal access to data gathered by Federal, State, and local governmental agencies; and

identify models of successful Federal, State, and tribal programs in the areas studied by the
			 Commission.
